text:
P1: Cleo, are you going to the demonstration tomorrow to help stop the spread of nuclear weapons?
P2: No, Simon. I hate demonstrations. I have heard the police will be standing by with tear gas.
P1: Yes, but North Korea boasts it has nuclear arms.
P2: One hundred ninety countries have signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty but the issues are just too complex. There are two sides to every story. I don't understand it and I have no intention of going to a demonstration. Demonstrations don't seem to accomplish anything anyway.
P1: Several demonstrations have changed politician's minds throughout history. As a responsible citizen I think it is important to stand up for what you believe in.
P2: Leave it to someone else. As I said, if you listen to both sides of a story, both sides have some good points. Why should I demonstrate and risk getting hurt for something that I am not even sure is right?
P1: You are not likely to get hurt. This will be a peaceful demonstration. I have spoken to the organizer for the university group. He insists that this will be peaceful. He advocates if you want world peace, peace begins at home-and that means right here in this city.
P2: You go if you want, Simon, but I plan to study for my physics exam.
P1: You are not likely to get hurt. This will be a peaceful demonstration. I have spoken to the organizer for the university group. He insists that this will be peaceful. He advocates if you want world peace, peace begins at home-and that means right here in this city.
P2: Okay, Simon. I need to meet my sister for coffee now.
P1: Bye then. See you in physics class tomorrow
